newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: OPINION-Jim Middleton's Canberra Closeup - Taxing times.
newsitem.headline: OPINION-Jim Middleton's Canberra Closeup - Taxing times.

text.p: By Jim Middleton (ABC TV Political Correspondent)
Prime Minister John Howard may not look anything like Paul Keating and he hates any comparison with the man he vanquished.
But every now and then the prime minister uses tactics straight out of the Keating textbook.
Back in 1992, when the coalition was hounding John Dawkins over unauthorised loan approvals by the Kirner government, Keating devised one of the great political diversions of recent time.

Not only was it the occasion on which he branded the Senate "unrepresentative swill" but also -- taking his heart in his hands -- declared that if John Hewson won the 1993 election Labor would allow his goods and services tax (GST) through the Upper House.

Uproar ensued -- the coalition (with the notable exception of Howard) fell about in self-congratulation, Labor backbenchers looked like they'd seen a ghost, but any further pursuit of Dawkins was forgotten in the hubbub.

Later, Keating -- with his usual sense of metaphor -- described what he'd done as getting a big hunk of smelly meat, throwing it into the distance and watching the coalition hounds pursue it, having put them off the Dawkins scent.
It was quite a graphic demonstration -- arm movements and all.

Whether Howard is depicting his re-ignition of the tax debate in similar terms has yet to be revealed, but that's what it was -- a big hunk of smelly meat hurled out in the wake of a budget which has satisfied none of his key constituencies -- the battlers, big business or small business.
Talkback hosts -- notably Alan Jones -- were antagonistic to the savings rebate, a clear sign their battler audience didn't think much of it either.

Howard's extraordinary decision to declare a "Do It Yourself" means test didn't help either, inadvertently boosting Labor's argument that it's an unnecessary gift to the rich rather than a tax break for the needy.
Business condemned the budget's caution, stinging Howard who took any example of corporate criticism as a personal affront.
By Sunday, he'd decided enough was enough -- threw caution to the winds and clambered back on the tax cart he'd abandoned in 1995.
Then he'd declared the coalition would "never" embrace a GST. On the Seven Network's Face to Face programme, though, he was asked whether his tax reform programme would include a GST.
His answer: "You can't have reform unless you look at all the options." Code for "Yes."
Howard advisers insist the prime minister did have a process and a timetable in mind when he let the tax cat out of the bag. Also that he'd discussed the handling of tax with his senior colleagues.
At least one cabinet minister, though, suggested the whole thing was spur of the moment improvisation.
He also raised the traditional fears about managing the tax debate.
No government, he claimed, which had introduced a consumption tax had won the subsequent election.
(Not quite: de Gaulle was secure in France after bringing in VAT in the early 60s; Margaret Thatcher went on to win two more elections after doing the same in Britain.)
The prime minister's minders also say Howard was always going to have to address the tax question before the next election, and about 18 months out was the appropriate time.
Another political goal -- according to the sources -- is to box the ALP.
The government fears Labor's campaign stategy will be to spend the proceeds of the "coalition's" budget surplus.
Thus, they say, Howard's gambit was designed to force Labor to come clean on tax.

As it turned out, opposition treasury spokesman Gareth Evans came a bit too clean -- suggesting on Monday that Labor would be prepared to "look" at a GST if it could be shown to be fair and equitable.
Not the Beazley line, at all.
But the opposition leader claims to be pleased, too.

He thinks the contributions on a GST of Howard and Treasurer Peter Costello have liberated Labor in its handling of the tax hot potato -- that what the prime minister has done is to open up the tax options for the ALP.
On the other hand, there's big danger for the coaliton in failing to direct the tax debate.
The debate can now throw up all manner of expectatoins Howard will be incapable of satisfying.
The follow-up from Howard and Costello has hardly been tidy.
So untidy Kim Beazley believes, the coalition has opened the way for Labor to develop its own tax agenda -- without a GST, of course.
That's the trouble with diversions -- they can develop a life of their own, a life beyond their instigators' control.
-- Reuters Canberra Bureau 61-6 273-2730
